Instrument.name: Helium Abundance Detector for Galileo Probe
Instrument.description: The Galileo Probe Helium Abundance Detector (HAD) provided the first opportunity to measure the He/H2 abundance ratio of a Jovian planet and with high accuracy. HAD was a miniaturized interferometer that accurately measured the refractive index of the Jovian atmosphere, after removal of NH3, H2O, and CH4, in the pressure range from 2.5 to 10 bar. From these data the helium mole fraction (about 0.10) can be calculated with an estimated accuracy of +- 0.0015. The instrument used a two-arm, double-pathlength interferometer or Jamin-Mascart interferometer. The light source is a light emitting diode (LED) operating at a wavelength of 900 nm. An interference filter with a 15 nm passband aids in producing near-monochromatic light. A Jamin plate produces two parallel and coherent light beams. Four cells, each of length l = 100 mm, house the Jovian gas and the reference gas, which consists of a mixture of 27.64 percent argon and 72.36 percent neon, giving the same refractive index as a mixture of 11.1 percent He and 88.9 percent H2. Additional optical elements are the collimator, the inversion prism, and the objective. The inversion prim is very slightly tilted about an axis parallel to the incoming light beams. This feature, in combination with the objective produces a well-defined interference pattern of consecutive equidistant bright and dark fringes at a linear array of nine photodetectors. The detector allows measurement of the position and motion of the interference fringes in multiples of 1/8 of the fringe separation.
